4.2.2018 ADDITION
CHAPTER 11
LIBRARIES, CEMETERIES, AND LAKE REGULATIONS
ARTICLE 1
LIBRARIES
Section 11-101 DEFINITIONS.
As used in this chapter, the term "library" means the
public library created herein, the term "board" or "board of
directors" means the library board of directors created herein
and the term "director" means a member of such board.
State Law References: Library boards, powers, 11 O.S.
Section 31-101 et seq.
Section 11-102 CREATED.
There is hereby created a public library with reading rooms
for the use and benefit of the citizens of the city.
Section 11-103 CREATED; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT AND TERMS OF
MEMBERS; QUARTERLY MEETINGS; ANNUAL FILING.
A. There is hereby created a board of directors for the
government and control of the library, to consist of all nine
(9) members of the Council of the City.
B. The directors shall hold office and shall serve until
their successors are elected or appointed and otherwise
qualified, and such latter persons, shall without any further
act or conveyance become fully vested with all the estate,
properties, rights, duties and obligations of their predecessors
hereunder, with like effect as if originally named as a Director
hereunder.
C. The board of directors shall conduct regular meetings
to discuss library business at least quarterly during each
calendar year and otherwise meet in special meetings as deemed
appropriate to properly and faithfully execute their
responsibilities hereunder.
D. At least annually, the board of directors of the
library, in conjunction with the head librarian, shall file a
4.2.2018 ADDITION
list of directors, terms of office and meeting times with the
Oklahoma Department of Libraries.
Section 11-104 DIRECTORS NOT COMPENSATED.
The directors shall serve without compensation.
Section 11-105 RESERVED.
Section 11-106 RESERVED.
Section 11-107 ELECTION OF OFFICERS.
The directors shall, immediately after appointment, meet
and organize by the election of one of their number as president
and by the election of such other officers as they may deem
necessary.
Section 11-108 GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES.
The board shall have control of the library building and of
the supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms or
buildings constructed, leased or set apart for that purpose, and
shall, in general, carry out the spirit and intent of this
chapter. The board shall have power, with the approval of the
council, to recommend purchase of grounds and a suitable
building for the use of the library. All powers delegated to
the board of directors shall be executed subject to the approval
of the council.
Section 11-109 RESERVED.
Section 11-110 BYLAWS, RULES AND REGULATIONS.
A. The board shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and
regulations for its own guidance and for the government of the
library and reading rooms, or either of them, as may be
expedient, not inconsistent with this chapter.
B. The library or reading room established under this
chapter shall always be subject to such reasonable rules and
regulations as the board may adopt, in order to render the use
of such library and reading room, or either of them, of the
greatest benefit to the greatest number, and the board may
exclude from the use of the library or reading room, or either
of them, any and all persons who shall willfully violate such
rules.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
C. Any person who shall willfully violate any rules or
regulations regularly adopted by the board for the government,
care and use of the library or reading room shall be deemed
guilty of an offense and be punished accordingly.
Section 11-111 DAMAGING, DEFACING OR FAILING TO RETURN BOOKS OR
OTHER PROPERTY.
Any person who shall destroy or deface any book, periodical
or other property of the library, or who shall fail to return
any book, periodical or other property at such time as the same
is due to be returned, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
Section 11-112 USE, TRANSFER OF LIBRARY.
A. Any library or reading room established shall be used
as such, and for such other public purposes as the city council
may deem proper, and shall always be subject to such reasonable
rules and regulations as the city council may adopt, in order to
render the use of the library and reading room, or rooms of the
greatest benefit to the greatest number.
B. Any library already existing or hereafter established
may be transferred by the society, association or individual
owning the same, to the city on such terms not inconsistent with
the object of this chapter as may be mutually agreed upon.
Section 11-113 ACCEPTANCE OF DONATIONS.
A. Any person desiring to make donations of money,
personal property or real estate for the benefit of the library
or for the establishment, maintenance or endowment of public
lectures in connection with the library, upon any subject
designated by the donor in the field of literature, science and
the arts (except that lectures in the interest of any political
party, politics or sectarian religion are expressly prohibited),
shall have the right to vest the title of the money, personal
property or real estate so donated in the city, to be held and
controlled by the city, when accepted, according to the terms of
the deed, devise or bequest of such property. As to such
property, the city shall be held and considered to be special
trustees.
B. The city shall have power to accept, or in its
discretion decline, donations tendered as provided in this
4.2.2018 ADDITION
Section.
Section 11-114 ANNUAL REPORT.
The board of directors shall make, on or before the thirtyfirst
(31st) day of July in each year, an annual report to the
municipal governing body stating the condition of its trust on
the thirtieth day of June of that year; the various sums of
money received from the library fund and other sources and the
amount of money expended and for what purposes; the budget for
the library for the next fiscal year; statistics on the general
character and number of books and periodicals which are on hand,
are lost or missing, have been added by purchase, gift or
otherwise during the year; the number of persons attending the
library; the number of books loaned out; the general character
and kind of such books; and such other statistics, information
and suggestions as the board may deem of general interest.
ARTICLE 2
CEMETERY
Section 11-201 SEXTON.
The City Manager shall appoint a sexton for the city
cemetery. The sexton shall perform such duties as may be
required of him by ordinance and all other duties imposed upon
him by the council and shall work under their direction and
receive such compensation as the City Manager may direct.
Section 11-202 DUTIES OF SEXTON.
It shall be the duty of the sexton to have actual charge of
the cemetery under the supervision of the City Manager and to
locate and dig all graves. No grave shall be prepared, or
burial permitted, until the city clerk shall have collected the
purchase price of the lot and fees for preparing the grave, as
provided in Chapter 18.
Section 11-203 RULES.
The City Manager shall pass all rules and regulations
protecting and governing the municipal cemetery, the ownership
of lots therein, and visitors therein; and the violation of any
of the rules shall be an offense. All such rules shall be
entered in a book to be kept for that purpose and shall be
4.2.2018 ADDITION
posted in a conspicuous place in the cemetery.
Section 11-204 CEMETERY CARE FUND.
Whenever lots are sold or charges made for interments, not
less than twelve and one-half percent (12.5%) of all monies
received from the sale of lots and interments shall be
segregated and set aside as a permanent fund to be known as the
“Cemetery Care Fund”. The Cemetery Care Fund principal shall be
expended for purchasing lands for cemeteries and for making
capital improvements, if necessary. The balance of the fund may
be invested in the manner provided by law for investments of
municipal funds. The interest from the investments shall be
used for the same purpose as the principal, or in improving,
caring for, and embellishing the lots, walks, drives, parks, and
other necessary improvements on such cemeteries.
For the purpose of this Section, “capital improvements”
shall mean all items and articles, either new or replacements,
not consumed with use but only diminished in value with
prolonged use, including but not limited to roads and streets,
drainage improvements, water and sewerage improvements,
machinery, equipment, furniture and fixtures, all real property,
all construction or reconstruction of buildings, appurtenances
and improvements to real property, the cost and expenses related
thereto of rights-of-way or other real property, engineering,
architectural or legal fees, and payment for improvements for
which subsequent reimbursement is made to the Cemetery Care
Fund.
Note: Amended by Ordinance No. 2000-03 passed on 2-7-2000.
Section 11-205 CONTRACTS FOR LOTS.
All contracts for the transfer of lots shall be signed and
conveyed by certificate signed by the countersigned by the city
clerk, under the seal of the city, upon the payment to the city
clerk of the price of the lot as entered upon the list filed in
the city clerk's office. The certificate shall show the price
for which the lots are sold and specify that the person to whom
it is issued is the owner of the lot or lots described therein
by number, as laid down in the plat, for purpose of interment.
The certificate shall vest in the purchaser and his heirs a
right to the lot or lots, for the sole purpose of interment,
under the regulations of the city, or as such regulations may be
hereinafter amended. The city clerk shall keep a complete
4.2.2018 ADDITION
record of all sales and burials in books provided by the city.
All abandoned lots or spaces of lots shall be so declared by
resolution of the city council and such abandoned lots or spaces
of lots shall thereafter revert to the city. All monies
received by the city from the sale of lots or from interments or
from any other source shall be paid daily to the city treasurer,
who shall deposit same in the municipal treasury. Expenses
incurred for the upkeep, repair, and adornment of the cemetery
may be paid by the treasurer upon proper warrants.
Section 11-206 OFFENSE.
It is an offense for any person to violate any posted or
published rule or regulation relating to the government or
preservation of the city cemetery which has been adopted by the
City Manager. The commission of any act of trespass, malicious
mischief, or other thing which is prohibited by ordinance within
the city limits shall be an offense when committed in any
cemetery owned or governed by the city. Any person who commits
any such offense shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided
in Section 1-108 of this code.
Section 11-207 RESERVED
Section 11-208 FUNERAL DIRECTOR RESPONSIBILITIES.
The funeral director is responsible for contacting the
sexton and providing all relevant information about the funeral,
including but not limited to the time and date of the service,
and the kind of outside container to be used. The funeral
director is further responsible for submitting a proper form
signed by the funeral director, or the owner of the lot, or duly
authorized representative of the owner or the estate of the
deceased or may verbally authorize the Section to open desired
location which form shall both authorize the opening of the
space and releases the city from any liability.
Section 11-209 POLICE TO LEAD FUNERAL PROCESSIONS.
The police department of the city may take responsibility
for leading all funeral processions going to Grace Hill Cemetery
and within Grace Hill Cemetery to the cemetery lot location.
Section 11-210 RESPONSIBILITY OF CITY, PERMITS FOR MONUMENTS.
A. After arrangements with the funeral director are made,
4.2.2018 ADDITION
the sexton shall provide for the opening and closing of graves
upon the payment of the proper fees and receipt of any necessary
permits, as provided in Section 11-311.
B. Any person other than an individual owning the grave
site or a person related to the owner desiring to set a monument
at Grace Hill Cemetery shall first secure a permit from and pay
the sexton ty between the hours of 7:00 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.,
Monday through Friday. Such monument may be set at Grace Hill
Cemetery only during such aforementioned hours, except as
otherwise agreed to by the sexton, and only after the sexton or
his assistant has properly identified and located the exact
place for the setting.
Section 11-211 PRICE SCHEDULE.
The price schedule to be utilized in all transactions by
the city at Grace Hill Cemetery shall be as set by the city
council in the city's fee schedule.
Section 11-212 PURCHASE OF GRAVE SITES.
Grave sites shall be purchased in the following manner:
A. Availability of grave sites shall be determined by the
sexton;
B. Selection of the grave sites shall be approved by the
sexton, only after the payment in full made for the grave site,
and the execution and delivery of the cemetery lot deed;
C. The purchase price of any cemetery lot shall be paid
in full, before the opening of any grave, as provided herein,
except that the funeral director shall not be required to pay
for the lot or grave site if he proves to the city clerk prior
to the opening of any grave on the lot that the decedent or his
estate is unable to make payment therefore;
D. Arrangements for payment of the purchase price of lots
and services performed by the city:
1. Local funeral directors may include opening and
closing, tent, greens, device, and property charges in with
other expenses for a service and shall make payment to the city
by the following 10th of the next month;
2. Out of town funeral directors may make similar charges
4.2.2018 ADDITION
as provided hereinabove but shall make payment to the city on
the day of the service; and
3. After the cemetery lot has been paid for, as provided
herein, and the fees charged are secured by the city, then the
city clerk of the city shall issue a cemetery deed to the proper
owners.
Section 11-213 USE OF GRAVE SITES.
Use of the purchased grave sites will be made in the
following manner:
A. The owner or the duly authorized representative of the
owner or estate of the deceased owner or funeral director shall
contact the sexton of the city, with proof of ownership and
request the grave is opened, and sign the proper form
authorizing the city to open the grave and release the city from
all liability;
B. The funeral director in charge shall inform the sexton
of the grave site desired, grave site time and date and other
pertinent details concerning the opening and closing of the
grave; and
C. The sexton shall perform the requested services after
proper determination of the grave location and the approval of
the arrangements have been made.
Section 11-214 RULES, REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS.
The following rules, regulations and requirements shall
apply at Grace Hill Cemetery:
A. No glass decorations or objects or remembrances are
permitted in the cemetery due to risks of shattering by mowers
and line trimmers;
B. No curb or curbs, whether made of cement, stone or
wood, will be erected or placed on any property within the
confines of the cemetery;
C. No fencing of any kind shall be permitted within the
confines of the cemetery;
D. The planting of trees, shrubs, and rose bushes shall
4.2.2018 ADDITION
not be permitted within the confines of the cemetery unless
approved by the sexton;
E. The travel of wheeled vehicles such as tractors,
trucks, motorcycles, cars, on other than designated roadways,
within the confines of the cemetery will be permitted by
permission of the sexton only;
F. All Memorial Day decorations such as artificial
flowers, wreaths, grave blankets, etc., shall be removed within
seven (7) days after Memorial Day from any property within the
confines of the cemetery and, in the event the decorations are
not removed, the sexton shall remove the same without notice
should the decorations hinder the performance of his duties;
G. The owners of lots within the cemetery are responsible
for the removal of all unsightly boxes, trash, wire or other
items;
H. The sexton shall remove without notice all existing
trees, shrubs, rose bushes, or grass on lots within the confines
of the cemetery which is unkept or unsightly;
I. The placing of gravel, rock, cement or stone on
property within the confines of the cemetery is prohibited
except by permission granted in writing by the sexton;
J. No living trees, bushes, plants, or grass owned by the
city within the confines of the cemetery shall be destroyed
unless their presence in the cemetery is detrimental or
dangerous;
K. Entry into the cemetery after the cemetery gates are
closed and locked is prohibited;
L. No upright foot markers shall be permitted on newly
opened areas within the cemetery after August 1, 1989; and
M. On and after May 1, 1989, each burial to be performed
at Grace Hill Cemetery shall require as a minimum a cement
receptacle in which the casket shall be placed. The
specifications for and placement of the cement receptacle shall
be as approved by the sexton.
N. The provisions of Chapter 4 concerning Animal
Regulations shall be applicable to Grace Hill Cemetery and
enforceable as if the cemetery was located within the corporate
limits of the City.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
O. No dog shall be permitted within the boundaries of
Grace Hill cemetery. Any owner or keeper of any dog that
violates the provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of an
offense.
P. Weed killers (such as Round Up) shall only be used in
the cemetery by the sexton or designee.
Note: Passed by Ordinance No. 98-3322 on 10-19-98; certain
amendment approved by Ordinance No. 2017-17 on June 5, 2017.
Section 11-215 FUNERALS NOT TO BE CONDUCTED ON SUNDAYS.
No funeral shall hereafter be conducted within the
corporate limits of the city on Sunday, the first day of each
week.
Section 11-216 REPURCHASE OF LOTS FROM OWNERS.
Any owner of any lot in the cemetery desiring to sell any
lot(s) previously purchased from the City shall notify and
provide the sexton with the following documents:
1. A copy of the deed to such lot(s),
2. Any Last Will and Testament or other probate documents
necessary to prove that person purporting to be the owner
is in fact the owner of the lot(s),
3. The repurchase amount sought by the owner, and
4. A written opinion from the sexton regarding the need for
the lot(s) and an opinion on the lot(s) fair market value
and marketability for such lot(s).
The sexton shall deliver the documents to the City Manager and
City Attorney. The City Attorney will review the documents and
give a title opinion. If the City Manager, or designee,
determines that the purchase price of the lot(s) would be in the
best interest of the City, the City Manager, or designee, may
purchase the lot(s), with the purchase price paid from the
Cemetery Capital Outlay Account within the General Fund;
providing that no lot shall be purchased for more than 100% of
the price of the lot(s) at the time of original purchase of the
lot(s).
Note: Section adopted by Ordinance No. 2016-13 approved on
9/19/2016.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
Section 11-66 MAUSOLEUM RULES AND REGULATIONS
1. Any person desiring to locate a mausoleum in the cemetery
shall file an application with the Sexton containing a site plan
and all relevant information concerning the materials,
construction and placement of the mausoleum shall be included.
Such application shall be reviewed by the Sexton and such
mausoleum shall not be erected unless and until approved.
2. After reviewing the site plan, the Sexton shall determine
how many lots need to be purchased for the location of the
mausoleum.
3. Mausoleums shall be permitted on the Northeast corner of
Section V and such other locations as may be surveyed and opened
for mausoleum uses as designated by the City Council.
Mausoleums shall only be located in such areas appropriate for
such use and where the view of existing headstones will not be
unduly blocked from the roadway.
4. No mausoleum shall be higher than sixty inches (60”).
Sufficient space must be purchased by the person desiring to
place the mausoleum in order to provide two feet (2’) of open
space on each side of the mausoleum. Upon payment for the
spaces, the deed shall be transferred and shall be conditioned
for mausoleum purposes only; no in-ground burials shall be
permitted in a mausoleum area. No casket or urn shall be
placed which does not fit within the mausoleum. The entire
visible exterior of any permitted mausoleum shall be completely
covered with granite slabs.
5. Up to one (1) body, or one (1) body and one (1) cremation
(but only if placed at the same time or when the cremation is
placed first), or two (2) cremations per niche will be allowed.
No body or cremains shall be received for entombment unless it
is contained in a substantially constructed casket, urn or other
suitable container suitable for the mausoleum. The Sexton or
designee shall have full authority to refuse to accept for
entombment or inurnment any casket or urn for cremains deemed
unsuitable.
6. All entombments, inurnments, removals and disentombments
shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the City and
all federal, state and local laws, ordinances, and regulations.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
7. All removals and disentombments shall be done by or under
the supervision of the City’s personnel. The City will exercise
reasonable care in making a removal, but it assumes no liability
for damage to any casket or burial case or urn occurring in the
process of making a removal.
8. Floral memorials (fresh flowers) will be removed whenever
they are unsightly or at the discretion of the Sexton or
designee. The City will assume no responsibility for the
safekeeping of any floral memorial or container.
9. No structural change or addition shall be made on or about
any mausoleum, and the City reserves the right to remove any
such ornamentation or correct any such alteration at the expense
of the owner without being deemed guilty of any manner of
trespass.
10. If the mausoleum is destroyed or damaged for any reason,
the City may cause any remains entombed or inurned therein to be
either promptly interred elsewhere in the cemetery or delivered
on written request to the owner or representative of the
mausoleum in which they were entombed or inurned, or temporarily
placed in a receiving tomb pending restoration of the mausoleum
and upon restoration re-entombed or re-inurned therein, in such
case as the City shall determine in view of the extent of the
destruction or damage to the entombed or inurned remains, to the
mausoleum, the structure containing it and the advisability of
restoration.
11. The City reserves the right to correct any errors made by
it in granting any mausoleum right by substituting other
interment property of like kind, equal value similar location,
so far as possible, or as may be selected by the City, or by
refunding the amount of money paid on account of said purchase.
ARTICLE 3
LAKE REGULATIONS
Section 11-301 DEFINITIONS.
The following words and phrases as used in this ordinance,
unless a different meaning is clearly required by the context,
shall have the following meanings:
1. "C.C.C. Lake" means the lake southeast of the city
4.2.2018 ADDITION
together with all the land owned by the city or over which the
city holds easements, near to or adjoining the lake; and
2. "City lake" means the city's municipal water supply
lake located southwest of the city together with all the land
owned by the city or over which the city holds easements, near
to or adjoining the lake.
Section 11-302 PERMITS.
A. Permits for camping, camp locations, hunting, fishing,
boating, duck blinds, and private boat docks on or at the city
lake and C.C.C. Lake shall be issued and fees therefor collected
by the city who is hereby authorized to secure the proper forms
and make and issue the permits and the yearly permits are
effective on January 1, of the current year and shall expire
December 31, of the current year. Daily permits shall be
secured from the lake caretaker and the city clerk of the city
is hereby authorized to deliver the same to the caretakers. All
fees shall be paid to the city clerk of the city.
B. All persons having permits issued by the city for
camping, camp locations, hunting, fishing, boating, duck blinds
and private boat docks, shall comply with all applicable state
regulations.
C. All persons entering on or adjoining to city lake or
C.C.C. Lake for the purpose of camping, camp locations, fishing,
hunting, boating, or the use of duck shall be required to have
valid and current permits in their possession, issued in their
individual name and the fee therefor fully paid, except that the
following persons shall not be required to obtain and have in
their possession such fishing permits:
1. Minors under the age of sixteen (16) years when
accompanied by an adult;
2. Honorably discharged veterans of any Armed Force of
the United States who are duly enrolled on the records of the
United States Veterans Administration as discharged disabled
veterans to the extent of sixty percent (60%) disability or
more, providing the veterans carry on his person evidence of the
disability; and
3. Any person who is totally blind and who is actually
fishing and one person who is accompanying the blind person are
4.2.2018 ADDITION
exempt from obtaining a fishing permit.
Note: Subsection C amended by Ordinance No. 2015-26
approved on November 2, 2015.
Section 11-303 BOAT DOCK REGULATIONS; PERRY CITY LAKE ONLY.
A. The holder of a valid and current permit for a boat
dock has the privilege, providing he shall comply with the terms
of this chapter in all respects, to obtain a new permit for the
next succeeding year under the terms and conditions of this
chapter, providing that privilege is exercised and the necessary
fees paid for a current permit by December 1 of the expiring
permit year.
B. All boat docks shall be maintained in good repair and
areas around and including the dock shall be kept clean of
rubbish and litter. The person in whose name the permit for the
dock was issued shall be responsible for the condition of the
dock and the immediate area thereto and, by acceptance of the
dock permit in his name, agrees to observe all park and lake
rules, regulations and ordinances and failure to comply with the
rules, regulations and ordinances shall cause immediate
revocation of the permit and the dock shall be immediately
removed from the city property or the city will cause the same
to be removed at the expense of the holder of the permit. The
use of boat docks by other persons shall be by owner of dock,
permission only.
C. There shall be maintained at all times a distance of
not less than one hundred (100) feet between boat docks.
D. In the event a boat dock permit is not renewed and is
current or in the event the same is canceled as in this chapter
is provided, the dock must be removed from property owned by the
city within fifteen (15) days from the time of such expiration
or cancellation or the city shall cause the dock to be removed
from city property at the expense of the person holding the dock
permit and if cost of removal of the dock is not paid within
thirty (30) days of the date of the removal caused by the city,
then the dock shall b sold by the city without notice to defray
the cost of such removal and the dock owner does by acceptance
of the dock permit agree to the provisions of this chapter.
E. A dock permit must be obtained by the owner of the
dock and for the purpose of this chapter it is conclusively
4.2.2018 ADDITION
presumed that the person obtaining the permit is the owner of
the dock and the site location therefor must be assigned by the
lake caretaker in the area approved by the city council of the
city before a boat dock is moved onto city property.
F. Dock permits and the dock permit privilege renewals
are not transferable.
G. All rules and regulations of the State Department of
Health shall be rigidly complied with by dock permit holders and
all other persons and failure of compliance shall cause
immediate permit revocation and immediate removal of the boat
dock.
H. The city retains the right to require without
explanation or reason removal of any or all boat docks at the
city lake from city property. In this event the permit cost is
to be prorated and the unused portion, together with the
deposit, returned to the purchaser of the permit, providing the
dock is properly removed and the area cleaned within fifteen
(15) days after notice is given by the city to remove the dock.
Section 11-304 CAMPER AND HOUSE TRAILER REGULATIONS.
A. A permit must be obtained and the fee therefor paid
for campers and house trailers and the site location therefor
assigned by the lake caretaker in the area approved by the city
council of the city before a camper or house trailer is moved
onto city property. Site locations for designated weekend,
weekly or monthly camping sites shall be assigned by the City
Clerk. In the event that such a designated space becomes vacant
or abandoned, the space will be offered to the next name
appearing on the waiting list located in the City Hall.
B. All campers or house trailers shall be maintained in
good repair and adjacent areas shall be kept clean of rubbish
and litter at all times and the person in whose name the permit
was issued is responsible therefor. Failure to comply with the
provisions of this Section shall cause the permit to be
immediately revoked, in which case the camper or house trailer
must be immediately removed from city property. The wheels or
axles must not be removed from campers or trailers and must be
movable at all times.
C. Camper and house trailer permits are not transferable
and non-refundable.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
D. Trailers are ineligible for permanent residences.
Permanent residence shall be deemed to exist if:
1. The owner or occupant of such camper or trailer does
not have another residence or place within the City where such
person dwells, or
2. The owner or occupant occupies the camper or trailer
for more than one consecutive month.
E. All campers or house trailers shall be maintained in
good repair and adjacent areas shall be kept clean of rubbish
and litter at all times and the person in whose name the permit
was issued is responsible therefor. Failure to comply with the
provisions of this subsection shall cause the permit to be
immediately revoked, in which case the camper or house trailer
must be immediately removed from city property. The wheels or
axles must not be removed from the campers or trailers and the
same must be moveable at all times.
F. All rules and regulations of the State Department of
Health shall be rigidly complied with by permit holders and all
other persons and failure of compliance shall cause immediate
permit revocation and immediate removal of the camper or house
trailer.
Section 11-305 C.C.C. LAKE REGULATIONS.
A. Tube float fishing and row boat fishing is permitted
after compliance with permit provisions of this chapter.
B. Electric power boats, sail or row boats may be used or
placed on C.C.C. Lake with a speed limit of 5 mph or no wake.
No internal combustion engine driver boats shall be permitted on
C.C.C. Lake.
C. There shall be no skiing, including jet skis, at any
time on C.C.C. Lake.
D. There shall be no permanent use of C.C.C. Lake
property for campers or house trailers but the same may locate
at a site located by the lake caretaker for a maximum period of
one week after securing the proper permit and paying the fee
therefor.
E. No bass fish shall be taken that are in overall length
of twelve (12) inches up to and including fifteen (15) inches.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
Any bass fish within the length limits shall be immediately
released back into C.C.C. Lake.
Section 11-306 DUCK BLIND REGULATIONS.
A. All duck blinds shall be maintained in good repair and
areas around and including the blind shall be kept free of
rubbish and litter. The person in whose name the permit for the
blind was issued shall be responsible for the condition of the
blind and the immediate area thereto and by acceptance of the
blind permit in his name agrees to observe all park and lake
regulations, rules and ordinances and failure to comply with the
regulations, rules and ordinances shall cause immediate
revocation of the permit without refund of an unused portion of
permit cost and the blind shall be immediately removed from city
property or the city will cause the same to be removed at the
expense of the holder of the permit. In the event a blind
permit is not renewed or in the event the same is canceled as in
this chapter is provided, the blind must be removed from
property owned by the city within fifteen (15) days from the
time of such expiration or cancellation or the city property
shall cause the blind to be removed from city property at the
expense of the person holding the blind permit. If cost of
removal of the blind is not paid within thirty (30) days of the
date of the removal caused by the city, then the blind shall be
sold by the city without notice to defray the cost of such
removal and the blind owner by acceptance of the blind permit
agrees to the provisions of this chapter.
B. A blind permit must be obtained by the owner of the
blind and for the purpose of this chapter it is conclusively
presumed that the person obtaining the permit is the owner of
the blind and the site location therefor must be assigned by the
lake caretaker in the area approved by the city council before a
blind is moved or built on city property. At the time the blind
permit is issued, an option for the same location the next year
may be granted for an option fee and this option must be
exercised before the end of the current duck season by payment
of the blind permit in full for the next year. Blind permits
are not transferable.
C. The city retains the right to require without
explanation or reason removal from city property of any or all
blinds at the city lake or C.C.C. Lake. In the event the permit
cost is to be prorated and the unused portion, together with the
deposit, returned to the purchaser of the permit, providing the
4.2.2018 ADDITION
blind is properly removed and the area cleaned within fifteen
(15) days after notice is given by the city to remove the blind.
D. Decoys and blinds shall be anchored by weights only
and shall not be anchored by stakes or other objects driven or
placed in the ground.
E. The required deposit for the blind shall be refunded
to the person making the payment thereof providing the blind is
removed from city property within fifteen (15) days after the
last day of the duck hunting season and the site location is
restored as nearly as possible to its original condition. If
the deposit is forfeited by failure to remove the blind from
city property within the required fifteen (15) days, a permit
shall not be granted for the next year for a blind even though
an option deposit has been made.
Section 11-307 GENERAL LAKE REGULATIONS.
A. It is unlawful to cut, remove or disturb any plant,
grass or tree, either wild or cultivated within the confines of
the ownership of any city property without first securing
permission in writing approved by the city council of the city.
B. It is unlawful to trap, hunt, or disturb furbearing
animals, quail, pheasant, prairie chicken or wild turkey or any
other animal, fish or fowl within the confines of the ownership
of any city property unless provided for by permit issued by the
city on payment of proper fee. The lake caretaker is authorized
to permit for the hunting of snakes and turtles at the city lake
and C.C.C. Lake without a written permit.
C. It is unlawful to discharge any rifle, pistol, shotgun
or any other firearm within the confines of the ownership of any
city property except with a valid, current written permit issued
therefor by the city.
D. It is unlawful to operate on the city lake or C.C.C.
Lake any boat of any description which does not comply with
state law.
E. It is unlawful to bring or cause to be brought on any
property owned by the city dogs, cats or other pets unless
properly leashed, muzzled or caged except during duck hunting
season. Dogs, if properly controlled, may be used to retrieve
shot ducks and geese.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
F. It is unlawful to litter or destroy property or
improvements on any property owned by the city. All material
that might be litter must be placed in receptacles provided for
that purpose.
G. All trot lines or snag lines will be kept out of the
ski area, ski areas will be marked by signs or floats.
H. No house or permanent type construction will be
permitted on city property.
I. No person while intoxicated shall operate a vehicle or
boat on city property.
J. The use of profanity, drunkenness, indecent exposure
or drinking parties is prohibited on city property.
K. The riding of motorcycles or dune buggies shall be
confined to the public roads unless permitted in writing by the
city.
L. The city assumes no responsibility for any boats,
motors or any other equipment left at the city lake unattended.
M. No person or persons shall remove from the city lake
any water for irrigation or by truck or trailer without the
written approval of the city.
N. Speed limits on city lake property is twenty (20)
miles per hour.
O. Ski planes are not allowed on any city lakes.
P. It is unlawful to ski or use surfboards on city lake
without each person doing so wearing life jackets, and it is
unlawful to ski or surfboard in any direction other than
counterclockwise, and it is unlawful to ski or surfboard after
sundown, and it is unlawful to ski or surfboard on city lake at
any place other than in the main body of water.
Q. It is unlawful for a boat pulling a skier to come
within one hundred (100) feet of any object such as a boat,
skier, land, trees, etc.
R. It is unlawful to ski between the tower and dam.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
S. It is unlawful to give any false or misleading
information to any application for any type permit required by
the city under this chapter.
T. No person except park employees shall make a fire for
any purpose in the parks unless permission is given therefore by
the mayor or his designee.
Section 11-308 PERMIT FEES.
Permits for certain activities are required to be secured
from the city. Fees are for such activities are required to be
paid to the city for such permits. The required permits and
permit fees are listed in Chapter 18 or may be set by the city
council by motion or resolution. All persons, firms or
corporations desiring to engage in such activities shall first
secure such permits and pay such fees.
ARTICLE 4
PARKS AND RECREATION
Section 11-400 SWIMMING POOL FEES
The fees charged for admission to the Perry Municipal
Swimming Pool shall be as set out in Section 11-400 of the Fee
Schedule found in Chapter 18. Pool hours shall be established
by the City Manager.
Section 11-401 DEFINITIONS
For purpose of this Article, the definitions contained in
Article 3 of this Chapter and the following definitions shall
have the following meaning:
“City park” shall mean all public parks owned and operated
by the City but shall not include C.C.C. Lake or the City Lake.
Section 11-402 CLOSING HOURS FOR CITY PARKS
A. City parks shall be open daily to the public on the
following schedule:
1. Between 6:00 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. every day from the
first day of April to the first day of November.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
2. From a half hour before sunrise to a half hour after
sunset of every day from the first day of November to the first
day of April.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons other
than city personnel conducting city business therein, to occupy
or be present in city parks during any hours the parks are not
open to the public.
C. Baseball fields, softball fields, football fields and
soccer fields within the city parks, including the spectator and
parking areas of said fields, are excluded from the above
closing hours while said fields are being used for team playing
of baseball, softball, football or soccer. This exception is
extended only to teams organized by sports organizations that
have filed with the city an approved schedule of proposed use of
the fields.
D. Tennis courts within city parks are excluded from the
above closing hours while the courts are being used for playing
tennis.
E. Persons using track and exercise equipment at Century
Park shall be exempted from the above opening and closing hours
while engaged in exercise at such facilities.
F. Excepting park employees, no person shall make a fire
in any city park excepting in an approved and designated grill.
G. The keepers and watchmen of the parks shall, at all
times, have the assistance of the regular police force in
enforcing the provisions of this Article.
Section 11-403 USE OF AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT OR LOUD NOISES
A. No person, other than law enforcement officers or
authorized governmental agencies, shall install, use or operate
any amplifying equipment in a fixed or movable position or
mounted upon any sound truck for the purposes of giving
instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures, or
transmitting music to any person or assemblage of persons in any
public park of the city without having first obtained a permit
therefor from the City Manager or designee.
B. No person shall use any amplifying equipment or make
any excessively loud noises in such a manner as to disturb other
4.2.2018 ADDITION
persons in the park or on adjacent property.
C. The application for such a permit shall contain the
name and address of the applicant, kind and type of equipment
proposed to be used, the manner in which it will be operated and
the purpose or purposes for the operation of the same, and such
other information as shall be required by the city clerk.
D. As used in this Section the term “amplifying equipment”
shall mean any machine or device for the amplification of the
human voice, music or any other sound. It shall not include
standard automobile radios when used and heard only by the
occupants of the vehicle in which the radio is installed, or
warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles or horns or
other warning devices used only for traffic safety purposes.
Section 11-404 NO GLASS CONTAINERS IN CITY PARKS, C.C.C. LAKE OR
THE CITY LAKE
No person shall be permitted to carry into or possess any
glass container within any City park or C.C.C. Lake or the City
lake.
Section 11-405 NO COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION IN CITY PARKS, C.C.C.
LAKE OR THE CITY LAKE
No person shall solicit, peddle, or engage in the business
of itinerant merchant/transient street vendor, coupon book
seller, or conduct any other commercial business enterprise,
excepting persons, firms or entities making sales or taking
order for or on behalf of the public schools or educational,
religious or charitable institutions, in any City Park, C.C.C.
Lake or the City Lake.
Note: This Article was adopted on August 6, 2001 by
Ordinance No. 2001-57.
4.2.2018 ADDITION
