that such connection would be unsafe or any other reason based
on sound electric theory or principles.
4.2.2018 Addition
Note: Added by Ordinance No. 94-3217 passed on 8-15-94.
ARTICLE 4
WATER SERVICE
Section 17-401 APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE.
When any person desires to connect with the water system of
the city, he shall apply to the office of the Utility
Superintendent for a written permit, which shall bear the name
of the applicant, the location of the property to be served,
including the street name, lot and block number, and the class
or kind of service for which it is to be used, together with the
name of the plumber or contractor who has been employed to do
the work.
Section 17-402 METERS.
A. All tapping shall be paid for by the consumer,
including all necessary fittings, work and material used in
connection therewith. The city will furnish all meters and
necessary fittings for installing same together with suitable
box for same where necessary, excepting where a meter of larger
capacity than one inch is required, in such case the consumer
will be required to purchase and install same at his own expense
under the supervision of the superintendent, the meter to be of
standard manufacture and of a type approved by the department,
and shall apply to all present and future users of meters.
B. The city will keep in good repair at its own expense all
water meters of its own installation, excepting where meters
have been damaged by carelessness or wrong doing of the user,
when same shall be repaired and charged against the consumer.
4.2.2018 Addition
Section 17-403 THEFT OF WATER.
Any person, firm, or corporation who shall by fraud or
stealth in any way obtain water service without having first
made application to the office of the department in regular
form, shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof
shall be punished accordingly. The amount of water that has
been obtained by any person, firm or corporation without such
water having been permitted to go through the meter designated
and placed for such person, firm, or corporation shall be
estimated by the average amount used by such person, firm, or
corporation during the past three (3) months that meter
operated, and the person, firm or corporation shall pay for same
at the rate fixed by authority of the city ordinances. In any
case where thereafter is committed, the city shall have the
right at the expense of the owner to install a boot and lock for
the water meter and pit as a precaution against further theft.
Section 17-404 FAILURE OF WATER SUPPLY.
In case the supply of water shall fail, whether from
natural causes or accidents of any kind, the city shall not be
liable for any damage of any kind by reason of such failure.
Section 17-405 CITY LIABILITY.
The city is merely a supplier of water delivered at the
curb valve of the consumer's installation, and is not
responsible for any damage to apparatus, equipment, or other
property of the consumer, either from wear or tear or inherent
defects in the installation.
Section 17-406 WATER METER LOCATION.
The location of the water meter will be at a location on
the line extension to be designated by the water department of
the city.
4.2.2018 Addition
Section 17-407 MAIN VALVES.
All main valves throughout the entire water system are for
the exclusive use of the city in making repairs, extensions, and
other improvements; and no person, firm, or corporation shall,
under any circumstance, use or tamper with them without written
consent of the superintendent of the departments. All fire
hydrants and public hydrants of all kinds are directly under the
control of the city. Any person, firm, or corporation who shall
tamper with or secure water from any of these places in any
other way than that for which they are intended shall be guilty
of an offense and shall be punished accordingly.
Section 17-408 RESERVOIR, PUMPING AND FILTER PLANTS, TANKS AND
TOWERS.
It is an offense and unlawful for any party or parties to
loiter around, climb upon, or tamper in any way with the tower
and pressure tank or pumping station and filter plant. No party
or parties shall loiter about the reservoir or drainage canals,
climb upon the dam, hunt, fish, use boats on, or bathe, or wade
in the reservoirs or drainage canals; and the reservoirs or
drainage canals shall be under the supervision of the city. Any
party or parties guilty of such offense shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished accordingly, except that the council may at
their pleasure grant hunting, fishing, and boating privileges on
the reservoir or drainage canals from season to season and at
such rates as they see fit.
Section 17-409 REMOVAL BILLS; SPECIAL BILLS.
Bill rendered on vacation of premises or bills rendered to
person discontinued service must be paid on presentation.
Section 17-410 SERVICE REGULATION.
The authority reserves the right, in cases of emergency, to
govern and regulate the use of water to all consumers by
resolution or proclamation as they deem proper for the public
health and safety.
4.2.2018 Addition
Section 17-411 FLUORIDE.
In order to protect the health and welfare of the citizens
of the authority, from and after the effective date of this
chapter the quantity of fluoride in the public water supply
shall be controlled in such manner that the amount present in
the water served to the public shall be in conformity with the
policy, and subsequent changes thereto, established by the State
Board of Health.
Section 17-412 RESTRICTING THE USE OF WATER DURING AN EMERGENCY.
Water restrictions imposed by mayor. In case of emergency
caused by a shortage of water in the city water system, it shall
be the duty of the mayor to give immediate notice, by
publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city,
to the customers of the water system, restricting the use of
water obtained from the water system, as the mayor may designate
for so long as such water shortage shall last. Thereafter, and
until the mayor proclaims that the emergency is at an end, it
shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or entity,
directly or indirectly, to use water obtained from the authority
water system for any purpose or use specifically prohibited by
the public notice.
Section 17-413 WATER RATES.
The water rates to be charged shall be as set out in
Chapter 18 herein.
ARTICLE 5
SEWER SERVICE
Section 17-501 DEFINITION OF TERMS.
For the purpose of this chapter, the following are defined
as provided herein:
1. "B.O.D. (Biochemical oxygen demand)" means the
quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed in mg/1, utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory conditions for five (5) days at a temperature of
twenty degrees (20) Centigrade;
4.2.2018 Addition
2. "Domestic wastewater" means water-born wastewater
normally discharging into the sanitary conveniences or dwellings
(including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings,
factories, and institutions and commercial establishments;
3. "Industrial waste" means water-born solids, liquids or
gaseous wastes resulting from discharge, permitted to flow or
escaping from the industrial, manufacturing, or food processing
operation or process, or from the development of any natural
resource, or any mixture of these with water or domestic
wastewater, or distinct from normal domestic wastewater.
4. "Milligrams-per-liter (mg/1)" means the same as parts
per million and is a weight-to-weight ratio; the milligram-perliter
value multiplied by the factor eight and thirty-four
hundredth (8.34) shall be equivalent to pounds per million
gallons of water;
5. "Normal domestic wastewater" means normal wastewater
for the owner in which the average concentration of suspended
solids and five-day BOD is established at not more than two
hundred fifty (250) mg/1;
6. "Owner" means the City of Perry, Oklahoma, or any
authorized person acting in its behalf;
7. "Sewer use charges" mean those charges levied on users
of the wastewater facilities for the cost of operation and
maintenance of such works; and
8. "Wastewater facilities" means all facilities for
collection, pumping, treating and disposing of wastewater and
wastes, operated by the owner.
Section 17-502 PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
A. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged
any of the following described waters or wastes to the
wastewater facilities:
1. Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other
flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas;
4.2.2018 Addition
2. Any storm water, surface water, groundwater, roof
runoff, subsurface drainage, or uncontaminated colling water to
any sanitary sewer. Storm water and all other unpolluted
drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically
designated as storm sewers, or to a natural watercourse approved
by the owner, and as covered elsewhere in this chapter;
3. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than
one hundred fifty degrees (150) Fahrenheit or any discharge
which causes the temperature of the total wastewater treatment
plant influent to increase at a rate of ten degrees (10)
Fahrenheit or more per hour, or a combined total increase to a
plant influent temperature of one hundred ten degrees (110)
Fahrenheit;
4. Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or
oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100)
mg/1 or containing substances which may solidify or become
viscous at temperatures between thirty-two degrees (32) and one
hundred fifty degrees (150) Fahrenheit (zero degree (0) to
sixty-five degrees (65) Centigrade);
5. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The
installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with
a motor of three-fourths (3/4) horsepower, (seventy-six
hundredths (0.76) hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the
review and approval of owner;
6. Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron
pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether
neutralized or not;
7. Any waters or wastes containing objectionable or
toxic, or poisonous substances, or waste exerting an
objectionable chlorine requirement. Discharge of the following
materials into the sewer system is prohibited:
a. Antimony;
b. Arsenic;
c. Barium;
d. Beryllium;
e. Bismuth;
4.2.2018 Addition
f. Boron;
g. Cadmium;
h. Chromium (Hexa);
i. Chromium (Tri);
j. Cobalt;
k. Iron;
l. Lead;
m. Manganese;
n. Mercury;
o. Molybdenum;
p. Nickel;
q. Rhenium;
r. Selenium;
s. Silver;
t. Strontium;
u. Tellurium;
v. Tin;
w. Uranylion; and
x. Zinc;
8. Any waters or wastes containing obnoxious, toxic or
poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity,
either singularly or by interaction with other wastes, to injury
or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitutes
a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the
receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant;
4.2.2018 Addition
9. Any waters or wastes having pH lower than five and
five tenths (5.5) or higher than nine and five tenths (9.5),
having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or
hazard to structure, equipment and personnel at wastewater
facilities;
10. Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such
size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or
other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater
works, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud,
straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics,
wood, unground garbage, whole blood, animal manure, hair and
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups milk containers,
etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders, lime slurry,
lime residues, slops, chemical residues, paint residues or bulk
solids;
11. Any waters or wastes containing phenols, hydrogen
sulfide, or other taste-and-odor producing substances;
12. Any radioactive waste or isotopes; or
13. Waters or wastes containing substances which are not
amenable to treatment processes employed, or are amenable to
treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment
plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies
having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving stream.
B. No person shall install or allow to be installed a
house connection to the sanitary sewer system that is not
accomplished in full accordance with the plumbing code.
Section 17-503 UNSEWERED AND MISCELLANEOUS DISCHARGES.
A. The public sewer system and wastewater facilities will
be used, wherever such system is available, by all persons
discharging any wastewater or other polluted liquids which are
not otherwise prohibited, unless an exception is granted by the
owner.
B. No person shall deposit or discharge any wastewater or
other polluted liquids on public or private property, in or
adjacent to any natural watercourse, or in any storm sewer, or
in any area under the jurisdiction of the owner, without the
approval of the owner.
4.2.2018 Addition
C. The owner in providing approval will verify that such
wastes will receive suitable treatment within the provisions of
federal, state, or local laws, regulations or ordinances, before
discharge.
Section 17-504 INDUSTRIAL WASTES.
A. It is the intention of the owner to exclude industrial
wastewater from the wastewater facilities which might be
discharged by any non-governmental user of the facilities
identified in the Standard Industrial Classification, U.S.
Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented,
under the following divisions:
1. Division A - Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing;
2. Division B - Mining;
3. Division D - Manufacturing;
4. Division E - Transportation, Communications, Electric, Gas
and Sanitary Services; and
5. Division I - Services.
B. A user in the divisions listed may be excluded if it
is determined that it will introduce primarily segregated
domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences only.
C. If, upon initial passage of this chapter a prohibited
user locates within the area and wishes to discharge industrial
waste or industrial wastewater to the facilities, this chapter
will be amended or revoked in order to establish or revise
industrial cost recovery provisions, which may be in effect or
apply, of the State of Oklahoma, or the United States government
or any agency thereof, as applicable to the user.
D. No present user of the wastewater facilities of the
owner is hereby excluded or intended to be excluded from
discharging to the wastewater facilities by reason of the
passage of this ordinance.
4.2.2018 Addition
Section 17-505 INFILTRATION ALLOWANCES.
The allowable infiltration for all existing sewers is
hereby established at no more than two hundred (200) gallons per
inch of sewer diameter per day per mile for sewers twenty-four
(24) inches in diameter and smaller. All new sewers shall be
tested for infiltration in accordance with an acceptable testing
method.
Section 17-506 OFFICE OF SEWER INSPECTOR CREATED; DUTIES.
The office of sewer inspector is hereby created and
established and until otherwise provided for by ordinance, shall
enforce all ordinances relating to the connection, use and
operation of sewers, mains, laterals and direct sewers and shall
have the necessary rights of ingress and egress to private
property so far as is necessary in the proper and full discharge
of his duties.
Section 17-507 CONNECTING BUILDING TO SEWER.
Each building shall be separately and independently
connected with the public sewer when one is provided. If there
is no public sewer, a private sewer may be constructed when
plans for the same is approved by the sewer inspector.
Section 17-508 SANITARY SEWERS, ALTERNATE DISPOSAL.
When a public sanitary sewage system is not available, an
alternate method of sewage disposal for each lot may be
approved. All lots in residential subdivisions where septic
tanks or individual sewage disposal devices are to be installed
shall not contain less than twenty-two thousand five hundred
(22,500) square feet and the width of the lot at the building
line shall be a minimum of one hundred (100) feet. All such
lots to be serviced by private sewage facilities shall comply
with the regulations of the county and State Board of Health.
Section 17-509 PENALTIES.
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously,
willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover,
deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenances, or
equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person
violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest
under charge of disorderly conduc
4.2.2018 Addition
B. Any person found to be violating any provision of this
chapter shall be served by the owner with written notice stating
the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time
limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender
shall, within the period of time stated in such notice,
permanently cease all violations.
C. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the
time limit provided for in this Section shall be deemed guilty
of a violation thereof, and upon conviction thereof shall be
punished as provided in Section 1-108 of this code for each
violation. Each day in which any such violation shall continue
shall be deemed a separate offense.
D. Failure to pay monthly bills for water or sanitary
sewer service when due or repeated discharge of prohibited waste
to the sanitary sewer shall result in disconnection of any and
all services to the water or sanitary sewer lines of the owner.
Section 17-510 SEWER RATES.
The sewer rates to be charged shall be as set out in
Chapter 18 herein.
Section 17-511 SANITARY SEWER BACKUP PREVENTION PROGRAM.
A. Any customer of the City’s sanitary sewer system who
suffers damage to their home, building or structure caused by
the public sanitary sewer system backing up into the customer’s
private property, and not due to the negligence of the customer,
may file an application with the City Clerk for the
reimbursement of 50% of the cost of installing a backflow
prevention system on their property to alleviate future events.
The application shall contain such information as required by
the Mayor, shall contain a verification clause and all receipts
attached that show that the work has been performed and the
equipment installed and paid for by the customer.
4.2.2018 Addition
B. No reimbursement shall be made unless the customer (1)
first files a claim with the City’s insurance carrier and is
refused payment by the insurance carrier, and (2) installs the
backflow prevention system, and (3) executes a contract with the
City permitting the right, but not the duty or obligation, to
inspect such backflow prevention system, and (4) signs a release
and waiver releasing the City and all its employees and officers
from any and all liability based on the sewer backflow
occurrence and any and all damage that may be occasioned in the
future by the backflow prevention system.
C. All applications must be filed within ninety (90) days
after the date the customer is notified that the City’s
insurance will not be paying said claim. The maximum amount
paid on any application shall be $250.00. Such funds shall be
allocated on a first come, first served basis, from monies
contained in a special account within the Perry Municipal
Authority established for this purpose. Reimbursements shall
not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the actual cost of the
installation of the backflow prevention system, which system
shall include a shut-off valve and/or sump pump.
D. In the event that the City is deemed to be legally
liable for the damages due to the backflow of sewage into any
home, building or structure, any such claim or judgment shall be
paid in accordance with the City’s insurance and not in
accordance with this Section.
E. Nothing contained in this Section shall be deemed to
place any duty or obligation on the City or Authority to pay
such funds to any person, such program being at the sole option
and discretion of the City Council of the City.
Note: Ordinance 99-3338 passed on 5-17-99.
Section 17-512 REGULATING SANITARY SEWER CONNECTION FOR THE
PURPOSE OF ELIMINATING THE INTRODUCTION OF PROHIBITED WATERS
INTO THE PERRY SEWER SYSTEM; PROVIDING FOR PERIODIC INSPECTIONS
AND/OR TESTS OF SEWER LINES AND FACILITIES OF HOMES, BUILDINGS
AND APPURTENANCES CONNECTED TO SAID SEWER, PROVIDING FOR
PENALTIES AND VIOLATIONS THEREOF.
1. Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates
otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this Section shall be as
follows:
"Compliance" shall, wherever necessary, mean compliance
4.2.2018 Addition
with the provisions of the Section set forth herein, and any
amendments thereto and/or the provisions of this Section;
“System" shall mean all of the facilities for collecting,
pumping, treating and disposing of sewage owned by the City
within the sanitary sewer service area of the City of Perry;
"City Council" shall mean the City Council of the City;
"City Manager" shall mean the City Manager of the City;
"Employees" shall, wherever necessary, mean and include
such employees or designated representative or officials of the
Perry Wastewater Treatment facility as the City Manager shall,
from time to time, designate and utilize in making the
inspection and/or tests hereafter described in carrying out the
other duties as prescribed herein to be performed on behalf of
the City;
“User" shall mean the owner, lessee or occupant of the
property on which the buildings and/or appurtenances that are
connected to the System are located.
Throughout this Section, the masculine gender shall be
deemed to include the feminine and/or the neuter, the singular,
the plural and vice versa, wherever required by the contest.
2. Following the passage and adoption of the this Section
by the City Council of the City of Perry, all users of the
sanitary sewage treatment and collection system of the City
shall, on or before August 1, 2014, bring themselves into
voluntary compliance with the terms and conditions of this
Section, and any amendments thereto, and all other provisions of
the municipal code, including but not limited to Section 17-502,
governing connection to and use of the sanitary sewage treatment
and collection system of the City, including but not limited to
the requirements of this Section set forth herein. No
connection
3. Upon expiration of the term provided for in Section 2,
a User utilizing the System of the City may avoid the imposition
or levy of any fines, fees, charges or penalties with regard to
such use and utilization by presentation of proof of compliance
and continuing compliance with the provisions of this Section,
and any amendments thereto, and all other provisions of the
municipal code, including but not limited to Section 17-502,
which proof shall consist of and include compliance with the
4.2.2018 Addition
following procedures and conditions as to each building and/or
appurtenance connected thereto:
A. Upon request by a Sewage Official or one of its
designated employees, either in writing or by personal contact,
each user utilizing the system shall, within ten (10) business
days, as to each building and/or appurtenance so connected to
the system execute a "Grant of Inspection" to the City, to
permit entry upon the property served by the System on which the
building and/or appurtenances are located, to inspect and/or
perform such tests as may be deemed necessary by the City to
verify and prove compliance with the provisions of this Section
and any amendments thereto, and all other provisions of the
municipal code, including but not limited to Section 17-502.
B. The Grant of Inspection shall be deemed to include the
right of periodic inspections and/or tests thereafter, as may be
reasonably determined to be necessary by the City, to maintain,
monitor and ensure continued compliance with the provisions of
this Section, and any amendments thereto, and all other
provisions of the municipal code, including but not limited to
Section 17-502.
C. Once a Grant of Inspection has been executed, it shall
be deemed to be an ongoing authorization as provided for herein.
Once a Grant of inspection has been executed, it may not be
revoked by the original grantor.
D. Reasonable written notice of at least twenty-four (24)
hours shall be given by the City or designated employee to the
User of the time and place at which the inspections and/or tests
provided for herein are to be made.
E. There shall be no fees charged for any inspections to
conducted and performed by the designated representatives.
F. In the event a User utilizing the System executes the
Grant of Inspection, and the City determines that said buildings
and/or appurtenances are in compliance, no surcharge, fines or
other penalties shall be imposed or levied upon the User;
provided, however, that the City shall have the right and
authority, pursuant to the Grant of Inspection executed as
required hereby and the terms of this Section, to conduct
additional inspection and/or tests at a later date to determine
that compliance still exists.
4.2.2018 Addition
G. in the event a User utilizing the System fails or
refuses to execute a Grant of Inspection to the City for the
purposes provided for herein, a surcharge of Fifty Dollars
($50.00) per month shall be imposed in addition to all other
charges authorized and imposed under the Perry Municipal Code,
as amended, commencing at the next billing period following the
date of the failure and refusal to execute the Grant of
Inspection to the City. if the User continues to refuse to
execute a Grant of Inspection after a period of sixty (60) days,
the surcharge shall be raised to One Hundred Dollars ($100.00)
per month.
H. In the event a User utilizing the System executes the
Grant of Inspection, and the City inspects, conducts tests, and
determines that the buildings and/or appurtenances of said User
are not in compliance with this Section, and any amendments
thereto, and all other provisions of the municipal code,
including but not limited to Section 17-502, then and in such
event, the City by its designated employee shall provide written
notice of the results of the inspection and tests to the User,
who shall be required to permanently comply with the applicable
provisions of this Section, and any amendments thereto, and all
other provisions of the municipal code, including but not
limited to Section 17-502, within forty-five (45) days of the
date of the notice.
I. In the event that the building and/or appurtenances of
the User are determined not to be in compliance with this
Section, and any amendments thereto, and all other provisions of
the municipal code, including but not limited to Section 17-502,
and the time period referred to herein for corrective work
expires, and the User refuses or fails to bring buildings and/or
appurtenances in compliance with this Section, and any
amendments thereto, and all other provisions of the municipal
code, including but not limited to Section 17-502, a surcharge
of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) per billing account for such
User shall be imposed, in addition to all other charges
authorized and imposed under the Municipal Code of the City,
commencing at the next billing period following the date of the
inspection or testing by the City wherein such non-compliance
was determined, for permitting such violation to continue to
exist.
J. The surcharge referred to herein shall be removed only
upon the following conditions:
4.2.2018 Addition
1. The User utilizing the System executes a Grant of
Inspection to the City or takes the required corrective action
required to bring about Compliance; and
2. The City inspects and/or performs tests on the
buildings and/or pertinences connected to the System and
determines that the buildings and/or appurtenances so connected
to the System are in Compliance; and
3. The payment in full of all surcharges billed to the
User utilizing the System until the time period the buildings
and/or appurtenances in question of the User are determined to
be in compliance.
K. The failure or refusal by the User utilizing the
System to execute a Grant of inspection or to cause his
buildings and/or appurtenances to be in compliance, after being
determined not to be in compliance, within the statutory
guidelines from date of the failure, refusal or notice of noncompliance
shall cause the City, by its Wastewater Treatment
Plant Supervisor or other City official, to prepare a Notice of
Violation of this Section as to the property and to file the
Notice for recording in the Office of the County Clerk of Noble
County, Oklahoma.
4. In the event a User is found to be in compliance and
subsequent inspections and/or tests determine that noncompliance
now exists, the terms and provisions of Section 3,
paragraphs D, H, I and J, thereof shall be applicable, except
that in addition to the surcharge to be charged in accordance
with Section 3, Paragraph I, if any, the User shall be liable
for payment of a sum equal to the sum of the months since the
original determination of compliance was made, multiplied by the
monthly surcharge amount provided for in Section 3, Paragraph I,
for knowingly, willfully and/or intentionally creating or
permitting such violation to commence and continue.
5. In the event a User if found to be in a state of noncompliance
a second or subsequent time, then the User shall be
liable for the payment of a sum equal Five Hundred Dollars
($500.00), plus an amount equal to the sum of the months since
the original non-compliance was corrected (and if never
corrected, from the date of such non-compliance determination),
multiplied by the monthly surcharge amount provided for in
Section 3, Paragraph I or G, for knowingly, willfully and/or
intentionally permitting such violation to commence and
4.2.2018 Addition
continue; each such day of continued noncompliance shall be
considered an additional vio9lation.
6. Any User violating any of the provisions of this
Section, and any amendments thereto, and all other provisions of
the municipal code, including but not limited to Section 17-502,
shall be liable to the City for any expenses, costs and fees,
including but not limited to reasonable attorney fees,
occasioned or caused to the City by reason of seeking
enforcement of this Section against the violator, as well as for
any losses or damages occasioned or cause to the City or the
System's Users by reason of such violation.
7. The City Council of the City of Perry shall have full
power and authority to invoke any legal, equitable or special
remedy for the enforcement of this Section. In addition, the
City Council is hereby authorized to institute proceedings on
behalf of the City in the District Court of Noble County or
other appropriate state or federal forum, for prohibitory or
mandatory injunctive relief to prevent of discontinue any
violations of this Section.
8. This Section shall be deemed supplemental to all other
ordinances and provisions thereof for enforcement and compliance
purposes, and shall not be deemed to amend or rescind said other
ordinances and provisions; further, that any fines, fees,
charges or penalties levied or imposed pursuant to this Section
shall be in addition to any fines, fees, charges or penalties
levied or imposed pursuant to all other ordinances and
provisions thereof.
9. The City Council of the City of Perry, by passage
hereof, has determined that the measures hereinbefore set out
are a reasonable means of ensuring compliance with the Section
set forth herein and any amendments thereto, and further that
the same are necessary to protect and ensure the health, safety
and welfare of the residents of the City and the area served by
the System.
4.2.2018 Addition
ARTICLE 6
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
Section 17-601 DEFINITIONS
For purpose of this Article, the following words shall have
the following meanings:
A. Bags: Weather resistant plastic bags, securely tied
about the top, and of sufficient strength to hold the load when
picked up and carried without supporting the bottom, into which
all residential users shall place their garbage and refuse. If
the garbage and refuse is placed in such properly secured
plastic bags, the plastic bags can be placed for collection
without the necessity of placing such plastic bags in a
secondary container or other trash can. If the Contractor
provides poly-carts, the garbage and refuse must be bagged as
provided herein before placement into the poly-cart.
B. Bulky Waste: Stoves, refrigerators, water tanks,
washing machines, furniture and other waste materials other than
Construction Debris, Dead Animals or Hazardous Waste with
weights or volumes greater than those allowed for Bins or
Containers, as the case may be.
C. City: The City of Perry, Oklahoma.
D. Collectible limbs and brush: Trees, shrubs and brush
trimmings, placed for collection by the Contractor, securely
tied together forming an easily handled package, not exceeding
four (4) feet in length or 50 lbs. in weight, and placed at the
regular place of collection.
E. Commercial and Industrial Unit: All premises, locations
or entities, public or private, requiring solid waste
collection, not a Residential Unit.
F. Construction Debris: Waste building materials resulting
from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations.
G. Container: A two (2) cubic yard receptacle used for
commercial and industrial solid waste users.
4.2.2018 Addition
H. Contractor: The person, corporation or partnership
performing solid waste collection and disposal services for the
City.
I. Dead Animal: Animals that have expired from any
cause.
J. Disposal Site: A solid waste depository, including but
not limited to sanitary landfills and/or convenience centers,
licensed, permitted or approved to receive for processing or
final disposal of solid waste by all governmental bodies and
agencies having jurisdiction and requiring such licenses,
permits or approvals.
K. Garbage: Every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable
and/or other matter) that results from the preparation,
processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning,
storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish,
fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter
(including, but not by way of limitation, used tin cans and
other food containers; and all putrescible or easily
decomposable waste animal or vegetable matter which is likely to
attract flies or rodents); excepting (in all cases) any matter
included in the definition of Bulky Waste, Construction Debris,
Dead Animals, Hazardous Waste or Rubbish.
L. Hazardous Waste: Any chemical, compound, mixture,
substance or article which is designated by the United States
Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate agency of the
State to be "hazardous" as that term is defined by or pursuant
to Federal or State Law.
M. Location: All bags or poly-carts for residential
collection shall be located in the alley (or within ten feet
(10') of the traveled portion of the roadway or street, if no
alley access exists) or at such other location on the user's
premises as designated by the City Manager or designee. For
disabled residential users, the term “location” shall mean
placement of the garbage and refuse not more than seventy-five
feet (75') from the street.
N. Refuse: This term shall refer to Rubbish, Bulky Waste,
Construction Debris and Collectible limbs and brush.
4.2.2018 Addition
O. Residential Unit: A dwelling within the corporate
limits of the City occupied by a person or group of persons
comprising not more than two families. A Residential Unit shall
be deemed occupied when either water or electric services are
being supplied thereto. A condominium dwelling, whether of
single or multilevel construction, consisting of four or more
continuous or separate single-family dwelling units, shall be
treated as a Unit, with a common refuse container or containers,
except that each single-family dwelling within any such Unit
will be billed either separately as a Residential Unit or
collectively on a single bill to the management as a multiple of
Residential Units an appropriate extension of the residential
rates.
P. Rubbish: All waste wood, wood products, tree trimmings,
grass cuttings, dead plants, weeds, leaves, sawdust, printed
matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded
mattresses, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded
shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such
as are used for packaging, or wrapping, crockery and glass,
ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic
substances, and any and all other waste materials not included
in the definition of Bulky Waste, Construction Debris, Dead
Animals, Garbage or Hazardous Waste.
Q. User: An occupant of a Commercial, Industrial, or
Residential Unit who generates refuse.
Section 17-602 USE REQUIRED
Except as herein otherwise authorized by the City Manager
or designee, all garbage and refuse accumulated in the City
shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the City, or the
Contractor, and not by any other person.
4.2.2018 Addition
Section 17-603 CITY MANAGER OR DESIGNEE
All garbage and refuse accumulated in the City shall be
collected, conveyed and disposed of by the Contractor, under the
supervision of the City Manager or designee. The City Manager
or designee is hereby authorized to implement the duties and
obligations of the City and to supervise the actions of the
Contractor pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Contract
in effect between the City and Contractor (hereinafter the
“Contract”). Such Contract, and any amendment thereto in the
future, is hereby incorporated into this Article by reference as
if fully set out.
Section 17-604 COLLECTION PRACTICES--GENERALLY
A. Collection Location. Garbage and refuse shall be placed
for collection by all users in a location as directed by the
Contract and City Manager or designee.
B. Poly-carts: If a poly-cart is furnished for use to the
residential user, it shall be used by such residential user.
Curbside residential service requires the placement of garbage
and refuse in bags and in poly-carts, if provided by the
Contractor.
C. Street Department Collection Center. Users may deposit
garbage and refuse as permitted in the roll-off dumpster located
at the Street Department Collection Center (“Center”). Any user
or customer making such deposit shall place cash or a check in
the required and scheduled amount, as provided on a rate sheet
located at the Center, which specific rate shall be based on the
volume of garbage and refuse deposited by such user or customer
at the Center, in an envelope, with the user or customer’s name,
address and telephone number provided, in the marked repository
provided for such purpose (“paid daily permit”). In addition to
paid daily permits, any user or customer may purchase monthly
permits at City Hall for a monthly amount as set out in Chapter
18, 17-607E, Part IV. Each time a disposal is made, the user
or customer shall remove a coupon attached to the monthly permit
and place same in the marked depository. Any person who shall
place garbage and refuse at the Center without paying the fee as
required herein shall be guilty of an offense.
D. Convenience Center:
4.2.2018 Addition
1. The Convenience Center is located in the NW/2 of the
NW/4 of Section 14, T21N, R1W of the Indian Meridian, Noble
County, Oklahoma, on city-owned property.
2. Any user may deposit garbage and refuse in properly
marked containers at the Convenience Center on Friday and
Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Central Standard Time, and
from 1:00 P.M. to 5:00 P.M., on Sundays, and for an extra hour
in the evening (until 6:00 p.m.)during Day Light Savings Time.
The Convenience Center shall be closed on all national holidays.
The Contractor shall accept and dispose of all garbage and
refuse delivered by any user of the solid waste service of the
City to the Convenience Center at no charge to the City or user
and upon proof of such user’s status (production of recent
utility bill showing payment of solid waste and disposal fee).
E. Cardboard/Paper Bins. Any person, firm or entity may
deposit cardboard, newspaper and paper products in any
authorized cardboard/paper bins. Cutting the cardboard boxes
open before making a deposit is encouraged but not required.
F. Sharing Commercial Containers. In commercial areas
where users have small volumes of waste, arrangements may be
made with the City for such users to share containers and their
cost. Such arrangements shall be made with the knowledge and
consent of the City.
G. Holidays. Collections will not be made on the
following holidays:
1. New Year's Day
2. Memorial Day;
3. Independence Day;
4. Labor Day;
5. Thanksgiving Day;
6. Christmas Day.
If a collection day falls on a holiday, collection will be
the following day for commercial and industrial users and on the
next regularly scheduled pickup day for residential users.
H. Complaints about Contractor to City. If any user
maintains the Contractor is in violation of the City's
ordinances or the Contract, the user shall report such matter to
the City Manager or designee who shall investigate same and take
appropriate action.
4.2.2018 Addition
I. Complaints about Contractor to Contractor. All
complaints made directly by users to the Contractor shall be
recorded in writing by the Contractor and shall be given prompt
and courteous attention. The record shall report the following
information: (i) name of complaining user, (ii) nature of the
complaint, including time and date of complaint, (iii) any
reason of Contractor for nonperformance, and (iv) the date and
time of correction by Contractor, if any. If, within any given
month, the Contractor shall fail to record any such complaint,
the same shall be deemed an act of noncompliance. The City may
review these records of the Contractor at any time. In the case
of an alleged missed scheduled collection, the Contractor shall
investigate and if such allegations are verified, shall arrange
for the collection of the refuse not collected within 24 hours
after the complaint is received or within eight (8) working
hours after a collection order is issued by the City, whichever
occurs sooner. Contractor shall, at its own expense, provide a
manned telephone answering service during regular office hours
Monday through Friday, 8:00 A.M. to 5:00 P.M., for the purpose
of handling complaints and other calls regarding collection and
disposal services provided by Contractor. Contractor shall
secure an annual toll-free telephone listing which can be used
at no cost by the users.
J. Rates Charged the Public. The City may charge the
users for solid waste collection and disposal services such
monthly rates as are set out in Chapter 18, Section 17-607E.
K. Miscellaneous Rules.
1. Users may place one discarded Christmas tree for
collection during the two-week collection scheduled by the City.
2. Extra refuse and garbage collection will be provided on
an on-call basis for each and every user. Extra refuse and
garbage collection may consist of unbundled landscape waste and
bulky items such as furniture, carpet and white goods, building
refuse resulting from demolition or construction projects, and
any other items too large for the regular solid waste collection
routes to accept. Extra refuse and garbage collection as
described above that cannot be collected by the regular solid
waste collection route will be paid for separately by the user.
Contractor’s price per loose cubic yard of extra refuse and
garbage collection shall be as set out in Chapter 18, Section
17-201, Part IV. These services will be by City Work Order with
Fee added to user’s utility bill.
4.2.2018 Addition
3. For large collection involving a roll-off dumpster, the
Contractor shall provide for the special collection of Bulky
Waste, Construction Debris and Dead Animals. The rates and terms
for such special collections shall be negotiated between the
Contractor and the user with billing and collection being the
Contractor’s responsibility.
4. Pickup at each user’s location shall be done in such a
manner as to avoid spills whenever possible. All materials
hauled by Contractor shall be contained, tied or enclosed to
prevent any leaking, spilling or blowing. Any spills that do
occur shall be promptly cleaned up by Contractor at no cost to
the City or the user.
5. Each user shall provide access to the Contractor to the
area where the garbage and refuse deposited for collection is to
be placed.
6. All provisions contained in the Contract and pertaining
to users shall be followed at all times by the user and
Contractor.
Section 17-605 STORING OF TRASH.
A. No person shall place any trash in any street, alley,
or other public place, or on any private property, whether owned
by said person or not, except in proper containers for
collection or under express approval granted by the City, nor
shall any person throw or deposit any trash in any stream or
other body of water.
B. Any unauthorized accumulation of trash on any premises
is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is hereby prohibited.
C. No person shall cast, place, sweep or deposit anywhere
within the city any trash in such a manner that it may be
carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk,
alley, sewer, parkway or other public place, or into any
occupied premises.
4.2.2018 Addition
Section 17-606 POINTS OF COLLECTION FOR BRUSH AND YARD TRIMMINGS
Collectible limbs and brush and yard trimmings shall be
placed within ten (10) feet of the curb of the street from which
collection is made or at the edge of the roadway where there is
no curb or at such other location as designated by the City
Manager or designee.
Section 17-607 OTHER MATTERS
A. The removal of wearing material, bedding or other
refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious or
contagious diseases have prevailed should be performed under the
supervision and direction of the City Manager or designee. Such
refuse shall not be placed in containers for regular collection.
B. Highly inflammable or explosive materials shall not be
placed in containers for regular collection but shall be
disposed of as directed by the City Manager or designee at the
expense of the owner or possessor thereof.
C. The actual producers of refuse or the owners of
premises upon which refuse is accumulated, other than
residential, who desire personally to collect and dispose of
such refuse, or persons who desire to dispose of waste material
not included in the definition of refuse and collectors of
refuse from outside the city who desire to haul over the streets
of the city shall use a watertight vehicle so operated as to
prevent offensive odors escaping therefrom and refuse from being
blown, dropped or spilled. All such collection and containers
shall be approved by the city. Disposal of such refuse shall be
made outside the limits of the city, except as specifically
permitted by the city.
4.2.2018 Addition
D. Carry out service shall be provided for the disabled
person if such individual provides certification to the City
Manager or designee that he/she is the head of household and
provides documentation from a recognized agency (social
security, veterans administration) private insurance company,
pension fund or other disability documentation acceptable to the
City Manager or designee and further certifies that no other
person or member of the household is physically capable of
placing the container for curb side service and further
certifies the address where the applicant resides. If such
documentation is approved by the City Manager or designee, the
user will receive carry out service at curb side rates. Any
person making a false or incorrect certification shall be guilty
of an offense and shall further be liable for the monthly
charges for carry out service for the prior months the person
received such service at curb side rates. Certifications must be
renewed on July 1 of each year.
E. The charges for residential, commercial and industrial
service are set out in Chapter 18 of this Code.
Section 17-608 USE OF ANOTHER'S TRASH CONTAINER
Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful
for any person to use another person's trash container, whether
the container is furnished by the city or the Contractor or by
the individual or some other person, without permission of such
other person.
ARTICLE 7
STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM SERVICE ORDINANCE
Section 17-701 STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM SERVICE ORDINANCE
AUTHORIZED
A. Definitions.
Unless otherwise provided in this Article, the following
words and phrases shall have the meanings given herein:
City shall mean the City of Perry, Oklahoma.
4.2.2018 Addition
Stormwater Drainage Management Program means the overall
strategy and framework for the stormwater management activities
of the City.
Stormwater Drainage System means any facility, structure,
improvement, development, equipment, property, or interest
therein, or other structural or nonstructural element made,
constructed, used, or acquired for the purpose of collecting,
containing, storing, conveying, and controlling stormwater
wherever located including, but not limited to, storm sewers,
conduits, natural and man-made channels, pipes, culverts, curbs,
gutters, and detention ponds whether public or private.
Developed real estate shall mean real property altered from
its natural state by the addition to or construction of any
impervious surface such that the hydrology of the property is
affected.
Impervious surface shall mean any hard surfaced area which
prevents or retards the entry of water into the soil in the
manner and to the extent that such water entered the soil under
natural conditions, causing water to run off the surface in
greater quantities or at an increased rate of flow than was
present under natural conditions, such as but not limited to
rooftops, asphalt or concrete sidewalks, paving, driveways and
parking lots, walkways, patio areas, storage areas, and gravel,
oiled macadam, or other surfaces which similarly affect the
natural infiltration or runoff patterns of real property in its
natural state.
Service charge shall mean the fee levied within the
boundaries of the City for the City's stormwater drainage
facilities.
Undeveloped Real Estate shall mean real estate unaltered by
the construction or addition of any impervious surface which
would change the hydrology of the property from its natural
state.
B. Service Charge and Exemptions.
There is hereby established a service charge for the City's
stormwater drainage system at rates hereinafter established;
provided, however, that the service charge shall not be imposed
on the following types of property:
4.2.2018 Addition
1. City streets, rights-of-way, parks, and open space;
2. State of Oklahoma highway or County rights-of-way; or
3. Undeveloped Real Estate
C. Rate Schedule.
The monthly service charge rate is hereby established at
Three Dollars ($3.00) for Developed Real Estate constituting one
tract of real property located within the corporate limits of
the City. The monthly service charge shall be capped at one for
each tract of real property under a single ownership without
regard to the number of lots or size of the tract.
D. Collection of Service Charge; Use of the Monies Collected.
1. The service charges herein established for the City's
stormwater drainage system shall be billed monthly on the
utility bill and may include such penalties as are now or
may hereafter be established for utility service bills.
The provisions for collection provided herein shall be
the rights or remedies which the City may have under the
laws of the State of Oklahoma.
2. All monies collected shall be placed in a special account
and used only for Stormwater Drainage System Projects and
pursuant to the City’s Stormwater Drainage Management
Program, as now constituted or hereinafter amended.
E. City Council Review.
The City Council shall evaluate annually, as part of the
budget preparation process, the financial needs of the
stormwater drainage systems and make such amendments to this
section which may be in the best interest of the residents of
the City.
4.2.2018 Addition
CHAPTER 18. FEE SCHEDULE
Pursuant to Section 1-112 of this code and for purpose of
providing a clear and concise listing of the fees and charges
authorized by the provisions of this code in payment for
licenses, permits and services performed in accordance with the
regulations and controls upon which the licenses and permits are
conditioned and to provide uniformity in the supervision and
administration of the issuance of licenses and permits and the
collection of the amounts prescribed, a schedule of fees and
charges, or fee schedule, is hereby set forth in this Section.
The heading gives the titles of the appropriate chapters and
articles as applicable.
Code Section Fee
Administration and Government
City Records
2-711 Search fee Actual cost to city
2-712 Prepayment of estimate fee
2-713 COPIES OF ORDINANCE AND OTHER PUBLIC RECORDS
1. For copies of documents having dimensions of eight and
one half (8 ½) by fourteen (14) inches or smaller, twenty-five
cents ($.25) per copy;
2. Thirty-five cents ($.35) for copies of each page
larger than eight and one half (8 ½) by fourteen (14) inches;
3. Twenty-five cents ($.25) per page if sent
electronically for computer printouts, without regard to the
size or type of page;
4. For certified copies, One Dollar ($1.00) per copied
page;
4.2.2018 Addition
5. Any authorized gun dealer in the State of Oklahoma who
requests a background investigation through the Perry Police
Department in order to effect the sale of a handgun to any
person shall pay a fee of $10.00 per background investigation.
This Section shall not apply to the following so long as
another fee has been established for same:
1. Complete copies of the city code of ordinances;
2. Copies of chapters or similar parts of this code which have
been prepared in booklet form; or
3. Ordinances which have been prepared in booklet form.
If the request for copies of public records is:
1. Solely for commercial purposes; or
2. Clearly would cause excessive disruption of the public
body's essential functions (i.e. requiring hand searches, high
number of requests or large volume of documents sought); then
the following document search fees shall be charged to recover
the direct cost of the document search, which is legislatively
determined to be:
a. Twenty-five Dollars ($25.00) per hour with a one (1) hour
minimum for computer searches; or
4.2.2018 Addition
b. Forty Dollars ($40.00) per hour with a one (1) hour minimum
for hand searches.
In no case shall a search fee be charged when the release of the
documents is in the public interest, including, but not limited
to, release to the news media, scholars, authors and taxpayers
seeking to determine whether those entrusted with the affairs of
the government are honestly, faithfully and competently
performing their duties as public servants.
The city clerk shall post a copy of the fee schedule on the
public bulletin board in the city hall and with the county
clerk.

3. Private Use of the Pool:
The pool may be leased to private persons for parties upon the
approval of the City Manager or designee.
Pool parties shall be scheduled by the pool manager at times
when the pool is not open to the general public; but shall not

the party for clean up and closure of the pool facility.

UTILITIES
Billing and General Provisions
17-201 Electric Utility Fees and billings in general
Without regard to the service period, all customers billed for
electric service mailed by the City of Perry on or after July 1,
2015, shall provide for payment of the following rates and
charges:
1. Electric rates for Large, Medium & Small Electric
Industrial Users, Commercial Rates and Meter Deposits.
A. Industrial & Commercial Definitions, Rates & Meter
Deposits:
Large Industrial User: over 100,000 KWH monthly
Medium Industrial: 9,000 to 100,000 KWH monthly
Small Industrial: less than 9,000 KWH monthly
Users and all Commercial
Electric Rates and Meter
Deposits.
(1) Large and Medium Industrial Energy Charge is: $154.97 per
month plus:
All kWh at $0.089 per kWh; and
The appropriate Demand Rate as provided hereinafter.
(2) Large Industrial User’s Demand Rate
a. The Demand is the kW supplied during the fifteen (15)
minute period of maximum use during the month, as determined by
the city's demand meter, but not less than five (5) kW;
b. The Demand Rate charged to the Large Industrial User
is $25.83 per month, plus
All KW of Demand at $5.11 per kW
c. The minimum bill for any Large Industrial User is
$46.23 per month.
4.2.2018 Addition
d. The minimum monthly kW is the kW for the highest
Demand established during the twelve (12) months ending with the
current month.
(3) Small Industrial Energy Charge.
a. Small Industrial Energy Charge is the Commercial
Electric Rate with a special minimum and choice of Demand Rate.
This Small Industrial Energy Charge is for typical monthly use
of less than 9,000 KWH.
b. The rate charged to the Small Industrial Energy User
is $19.12 plus
(1) First 2000 KWH per month at $0.127 per KWH plus
(2) Over first 2000 KWH at $0.10 per KWH
c. The special monthly minimum is $1.16/KVA of
transformer capacity (each phase is to be counted separately
when establishing the minimum; for example: 3-50 KVA
transformers is a $175.57 minimum). PCA adjustments are to
follow determination of minimum bill.
d. Further, a choice of Demand Rate shall be made.
(4) Standard Medium and Small Industrial Demand Rate.
a. The Demand is the kW supplied during the fifteen (15)
minute period of maximum use during the month, as determined by
the city's demand meter, but not less than five (5) kW.
b. The rate charged to the customer is $25.83 per month,
plus
c. All KW of Demand at $5.11 per kW. The minimum bill for
Medium and Small Industrial Users shall be $45.23.
(4a) Alternate Medium and Small Industrial Demand Rate
(Time of Use Demand Rate).
a. This type of service is Time of Use Demand Rate.
Medium and Small Industrial Users may elect and have Time of Use
Demand metering. Any such election shall commence with June
usage, be for a minimum of one year, and will automatically
renew until otherwise canceled.
4.2.2018 Addition
c. Summer usages: (months of June, July August, and September
usages).
All kW demand will be metered from 2:00 PM to 7:00 PM local
time Monday through Friday (15 minute intervals to determine
maximum use).
Each kW of maximum demand $7.644
Winter usages (October through May)
The billed usage shall be 60% of the maximum usage
occurring during the 4 summer months and to be billed at a
charge per kW of $7.644.
(5) Commercial Electric.
a. The rate charged to the consumer is $19.19 per month
(minimum bill) plus:
(1) First 2000 kwh per month $0.127 per kwh plus
(2) Over 2000 kwh @ $0.100 per kwh.
b. A special rate is available to commercial rate and
alternate industrial rate customers using one or more electric
heat pumps for space heating. Qualifying heat pumps shall have
electric resistance supplemental heat or no supplemental heat.
Each qualified consumer must make application to the city before
rate will apply; and
c. During each of the 7 winter months of October through
April, up to 250 kwh per KW of connected heat pump kW (excluding
supplemental electric resistance heating kW) shall be billed at
$0.087 per kwh. Heat pump heating kwh shall be the last kwh
billed and shall not exceed 50% of the total kwh billed each
month.
(6) Electric Rates to be Charged at the Perry Municipal Airport
A. Effective with the institution of electric service at the
Perry Municipal Airport, all users desired electric service
shall pay the following fees, charges and rates:
1. The deposit, permit and inspection fees currently
4.2.2018 Addition
charged for similar in-town installations shall be charged users
at the Perry Municipal Airport.
2. The fee for connection of service shall be $23.41.
3. The following rates shall be charged all such users:
(a) A base charge of $18.03 per month
(b) All kwh @ 0.121 per month
4. The City will work with the user to determine the
nearest point of delivery for all electrical
installations.
5. The user will provide or pay the cost of all
electrical equipment required for such user’s
installation.
B. Residential and rural electric rate and meter
deposits.
(1) Residential and rural rates for "all electric"
structures, and meter deposits.
The following are rates for residences and rural residences
with "all electric" service needs for October through April
billing periods: (Bills dated on or about October 1 through
April 30):
a. Minimum bill $8.41 per month, plus
b. First 1000 kwh per month $0.122 per kwh; plus
c. All over 1000 kwh per month $0.099 per kwh.
(2) The following are rates for residences and rural
residences with "all electric” service needs for May through
September (bills dated on or about May 1st through September 30):
a. Minimum bill $8.41 per month, plus
b. First 2000 kwh per month $0.122 per kwh; plus
c. All over 2000 kwh per month $0.105 per kwh.
(3) The following are Summer rates Non-all electric for
residential and rural residential usages for May through
4.2.2018 Addition
September: (Bills dated on or about May 1 through September 30):
a. Minimum bill: $8.41 per month, plus
b. First 2000 KWH per month $0.122 per kwh; plus
c. All over 2000 KWH per month $0.105 per kwh.
(4) The following are Winter rates for Non-all electric
residential and rural residential with electric usages for
October through April billing periods: (Bills dated on or about
October 1 through April 30):
a. Minimum charge bill: $8.41 per month, plus
b. First 1000 KWH per month: $0.122 per kwh; plus
c. All over 1000 KWH per month: $0.105 per kwh
(5) Residential and Commercial Distributed Generation
Customer’s Rate. Wind, Solar and other Grid-Connected Non-
Utility Owned Electric Generation Customers (hereinafter
referred to as “Residential and Commercial Distributed
Generation Customers” or “customers”) shall pay a customer
charge of $58.00 per month and the usage rate per month based on
actual metered consumption of $0.07 per kilowatt hour (kWh) for
the first 800 kWh used, after which use the per kilowatt hour
(kWh) charge shall be the same per kilowatt hour (kWh) charge as
provided for all other users in such similar class of customer,
which per kilowatt hour (kWh) charge shall be used to calculate
the rate as provided in this code. The City will credit any
customer 3.6 cents per kilowatt hour for any electric generation
received by the City from a Customer’s Generation system;
provided however, such credit shall not exceed the customer’s
electric usage charge for such billing period and once such
maximum credit has occurred, no further credit or payment of any
type for additional electricity received by the City shall be
made. No customer who constructs, installs or uses, or permit
the construction, installation or use of a distributed
generation service at the customer’s residence or business,
shall fail to notify the City of such fact by making a personal
visit to city hall at least ten (10) business days prior to the
date of such construction, installation, operation and/or use of
the distributed generation system. During such personal visit,
said customer’s rate shall be switched to the rate provided
herein and a date and time for inspection of the facilities at
4.2.2018 Addition
the customer’s home or business shall be set, and continued from
time to time as required, to ensure that the installation is
approved for use by the City, prior to its actual use by the
customer. Any customer who shall violate any provision of this
section, by act or omission, shall be guilty of an offense and
be subject to a fine of Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00), court
costs and all applicable fees and state assessments, with each
such day of continued violation deemed an additional offense.
C. General electric service conditions and rates.
(1) Rates shall apply to any customer for all services
supplied at one point of delivery and measured through one
meter. The rates are not applicable to resale, breakdown or
standby service.
(2) Customers are served by the city.
(3) The department will supply single or three-phase
service and any standard voltage from its distribution system
and through one standard transformation. Where entire service
cannot be measured at one utilization voltage with one standard
type meter, it will be measured at primary voltage.
(4) The contract period is for not less than one year.
D. Temporary Type Service (Oil Wells Etc.)
The consumer will pay an amount equal to the full amount
for construction of the electric lines for oil well or booster
pump locations.
The consumer will be reimbursed at the rate of ten percent
(10%) of their usage bill per month until the full amount has
been reimbursed. Should service be discontinued prior to full
reimbursement consumer forfeits further reimbursement.
A charge of $50.00 per month minimum on motors of ten (10)
horsepower or more will be paid by the consumer. A charge of
$25.00 per month minimum on motors nine (9) horsepower or less
will be paid by the consumer.
The charge for disconnection and reconnection of service
shall be $10.00.

b. $15.04 per month for each 175 watt metal halide or

c. $18.86 per month for each 400 watt metal halide or 400
watt LED equivalent security light installed on department pole.
d. $33.86 per month for each 1000-watt metal halide or
1000 watt LED equivalent security light installed on department
pole.
(3) The department shall be obligated to furnish lighting
from dusk to dawn and at all times replace and repair at its own
cost and expense all broken or damaged lamps, poles, and other
facilities used in providing this lighting.
(4) The contract period shall be for not less than one
year.

(1) Rates shall apply to any customer for all services
supplied at one point of delivery and measured through one
meter. They are not applicable to resale, breakdown or standby
service.
(2) The territory includes all customers served by the
city.
(3) The department will supply single or three-phase
service and any standard voltage from its distribution system
and through one standard transformation. Where entire service
cannot be measured at one (1) utilization voltage with one
standard type meter, it will be measured at primary voltage.

I. Service to potentially temporary locations.
In potentially temporary locations, the consumer will pay
an amount equal to an agreed upon estimate of the full
amount of costs for construction of the electric lines and
service equipment for oil well, booster pump or similar
type location. The consumer will be reimbursed at the rate
of ten percent (10%) of their usage bill per month until
the full amount of these construction costs has been
reimbursed. Should service be discontinued prior to full
reimbursement, the consumer forfeits further reimbursement.
Commercial rates as set out in the fee schedule with a
special minimum shall apply to the usage. A minimum charge
of $50.00 per month on motors of 10 horsepower or more will
be paid by the consumer. A minimum charge of $25.00 per
month on motors of 9 horsepower or less will be paid by the
consumer.
J. Purchased power cost adjustment (PCA).
Purchase power adjustment costs are based on a wholesale
cost of $0.061 KWH. Billing for each KWH sales will be
adjusted to properly reflect changes in the monthly
purchase power cost from the wholesaler suppliers. The
adjustment factor shall be as follows:
a. PCA = (A /B) - $0.061) X $1.164
Where: PCA is the additional dollars, either positive or
negative, rounded to the nearest tenth of a mill, per KWH to be
applied to all KWH sold to any each customer;
A is amount of the month’s billing OMPA power purchase
for total demand and energy charge without consideration of any
demand discount.
B is total KWH City purchased for the month;
$0.061 KWH is base purchase power cost in $/KWH;
1.164 is a constant reflecting system losses and unbilled
4.2.2018 Addition
city uses.
b. OMPA billings occurs 10 days after customers are
billed, therefore the resulting PCA adjustment is to be applied
each month based on customer’s prior month usage. The PCA
amendment shall apply for all billings mailed on or after July
1, 2015.
E. For testing electric meters, the charge is $10.00 per test

In order to encourage building renovation and development within
the downtown historic square, as defined by 6th Street on the
East, 7th Street on the West, Cedar Street on the South and
Delaware on the North (hereinafter the “square”), any building
located within and fronting the square which requires, as a part
of its building permit, pursuant to the applicable building
code, the installation of a private fire hydrants or fire
sprinkler systems, and which building will be used for retail
purposes, the costs of installation of the service line to the
building shall be shared by and between the owner or persons in
lawful custody or control of the building (hereinafter the
“owner”) as follows:
A. The City shall pay for all labor necessary to cut the
street, curb and sidewalk;
B. The owner shall pay all required connection fees including
the cost of the water tap, tap the main water line, install the
lateral within the street/sidewalk right-of-way and to the edge
of the building, pay the cost of all materials required,
including but not limited to pipe, fittings, concrete, and
brick, and make the connection from the lateral water line lying
in the ditch to the installation to be made within or upon the
building.
C. After final inspection, the City will pay the cost of labor
to retrofit the street, curb and sidewalk.
4.2.2018 Addition
The City may require a cash deposit not to exceed $500.00 to be
made in the amount of the anticipated cost by the owner prior to
commencing any work.
The fee charge for fire service shall apply to all systems now
or hereinafter to be connected to city mains.
C. Bulk Water Rates
1. The following rate is set to be collected by the city for
bulk water sales for raw water from the city's lakes: $0.70 per
100 gallons or fraction thereof.
2. The following rate is set to be collected by the city for
bulk water sales of treated water at the water plant: $1.00 per
100 gallons or fraction thereof.
Provided however, the City Manager may negotiate the rate
for the purchase of bulk water with third parties based on the
quantity of water to be purchased, provided such rate shall
never be less than the rate paid by Perry residential water
utility customers. Such water sales shall be evidenced by a
contract for sale in substantial form as that form approved by
the City Council.
D. Charge and procedure for testing meters.
Any person receiving water through a meter supplied by the City
who desires to have the accuracy of same tested, may do so by
making a deposit of Ten Dollars ($10.00) with the cashier of the
department. The superintendent will then make a proper test of
such meter and if after proper test it is found to be incorrect
more than two percent (2%) in favor of the city, the deposit of
Ten Dollars ($10.00) shall be returned to the consumer and
correction made only for that month for which the bill was last
rendered. If, however, the meter is found to be correct, then
the Ten Dollars ($10.00) shall become the property of the city
and be paid to the credit of the water fund. In case of a meter
failing to register, the monthly water rent due the city shall
be determined by an average of the three (3) previous months
that the meter registered. In all cases where the consumer's
piping or plumbing is divided, thus necessitating the use of two
(2) meters, each meter shall be handled and regarded as for
separate and distinct consumers to each of which will apply the
regular water rates and minimum charges until such plumbing or
piping is so arranged as to permit the use of but one meter.
Under no circumstances shall the consumption be added or
4.2.2018 Addition
"lumped" in order to reduce the net sum due the city.
III. SEWER USE RATES.
Section 17-510 SANITARY SEWER USE RATES.
A. Sewer Rates
1. Without regard to the service period, all customers
billed for sanitary sewer service mailed by the City of Perry on
or after January 1, 2019, shall provide for payment of the
following monthly rates and minimum charges:
a. First four hundred (400) cubic feet [or first three
thousand (3000) gallons] of water used (minimum):
$19.31 per month, plus $0.01363 per cubic foot of
water used above four hundred (400) cubic feet of
water [or $.00182 per gallon of water used above three
thousand (3000) gallons] during the months September
through April.
b. First one thousand (1000) cubic feet [or first seventy
five hundred (7500) gallons] of water used (minimum):
$19.31 per month, plus $0.01363 per cubic foot of
water used above one thousand (1000) cubic feet of
water (or $.00182 per gallon of water used above
seventy five hundred (7500) gallons) during the months
May through August.
2. Any rural user of the sanitary sewer system will be
charged double the above rates and minimum charges provided for
in Subsection A.1; and
3. In addition to the rates and minimum charges provided
for in Subsection A.1 hereinabove, without regard to the service
period, all customers billed for sanitary sewer service mailed
by the City of Perry on or after January 1, 2019, shall provide
for the monthly payment of the following Sanitary Sewer Capital
Improvement rates and minimum charges:
a. First four hundred (400) cubic feet of water [three
thousand (3000) gallons] or the first one thousand (1000) cubic
feet of water [seventy five hundred (7500) gallons] based on the
applicable month as provided in Subsection A3b or Subsection
A3c, respectively, used by:
4.2.2018 Addition
Residential customers located inside or outside of the corporate
limits: $6.90;
Commercial customers located inside or outside of the corporate
limits: $17.25;
Industrial customers located inside or outside of the corporate
limits: $17.25;
plus
b. For customers located within the corporate limits for
each cubic foot of water used above four hundred (400) cubic
feet per month , except during May, June, July and August, shall
pay $0.004497 (for each gallon of water used above three
thousand (3000) gallons per month except during May, June, July
and August, shall pay $0.0006); for customers located outside
the corporate limits for each cubic foot of water used above
four hundred (400) cubic feet per month, except during May,
June, July and August shall pay $0.008995 for each gallon of
water used above three thousand (3000) gallons per month except
during May, June, July and August, shall pay $0.00121); plus
c. For customers located within the corporate limits for
each cubic foot of water used above one thousand (1000) cubic
feet per month during the months of May, June, July and August
shall pay $0.004497; [for each gallon of water used above
seventy five hundred (7500) gallons per month during the months
of May, June, July and August shall pay $0.0006]; for customers
located outside the corporate limits for each cubic foot of
water used above one thousand (1000) cubic feet per month during
the months of May, June, July and August, shall pay $0.008995
(for each gallon of water used above seventy five hundred (7500)
gallons per month during the months of May, June, July and
August, shall pay $0.00121);
These minimum fees and charges shall be placed in a special
account and used only for the payment of any indebtedness
necessarily incurred by the Perry Municipal Authority to
engineer and construct certain Sanitary Sewer Capital
Improvement, including the costs of such indebtedness, with such
minimum fees and charges terminating automatically upon the
payment in full of such indebtedness.
B. Sewer tap fees.
1. All openings required to connect the public sewer line with
a private sewer line shall be made in the presence of the sewer
4.2.2018 Addition
inspector by a qualified plumber holding a current city plumbing
license, by the payment of a tap fee to be paid to the city
clerk, in advance, as follows:
a. Inside city limits, sewer tap fee $ 25.00; and
b. Rural user sewer tap fee $300.00.
c. Septage Fees.
The following fees shall be charged for depositing sewer waste
(hereinafter “septage”) from tanker trucks or other sources to
the sanitary sewer treatment facility:
Annual Permit (from January 1 through December 31 regardless of
time purchased)
$250.00
Monthly Permit (Minimum) for first 1000 gallons $30.00
Per gallon charge over first 1000 gallons $0.03 per
gallon
All such fees shall be paid in order to dispose of septage.
Septage shall only be disposed of in the manner as directed by
the City Manager or designee. No person, firm, corporation or
other entity shall dispose of septage within the corporate
limits of the City of Perry except as directed by the City
Manager or designee or without paying the fees for such service
provided herein.
